bboxes.raw_text:
BOSTON : Emotional problems
have served as the whipping
boy for childs reading diff
ficulty for too long. according to
a distinguished Boston Univer-
sity authority on reading edu-
cation for over 80 years.


Almost any child, regardless
Of whether or not he comes from
an emotionally or culturally de-
prived background. can learn to
read we'll, according to DR.. DON
aid Durrell Of Wellesley Hills,
Mass. professor Of education and
former Dean and founder Of the
University Reading Clinic.


1t all depends on how effec-
lively he is taught.


One Of the most important
elements in successful read
ing program is the teaching Of
phonics. according to results Of
studies published in the current
issue Of the Universitys Journal
of Education. The publication Of
Boston University Research in
Elementary School Reading,
lo33-1963," done collaboratively
by DR.. Durrell and Prof. Helen
A. Murphy Of Natick, Mass.
present director of the Reading
Clinic, marks the completion of
80 years of research and service
in reading problems at the Uni
versity.


The most effective phonics
programs were found to be those
based upon early ear training,
where the child moves from
speech to print, rather than the
reverse.


"f a child is having reading
difficulty the chances are not
that he has psychological prob
lens. but that he doesn't have
an ear for spoken sounds" DR..
Durrell said.

EXPERT DISCOUNTS
EMOTIONAL


PROBLEMS AS
READING FAULT

Mrs. Ida A. Woodward, nurse
at Palmdale School, urges more
young high school girls to think
of nursing as a profession.


A native Of Nogales, Arizona,
Mrs. Woodward received her
training from Nogales High
School and ST. Monica's School
Of Nursing.


She has completed some grad
uate training at Arizona State
University.


She assumed duties at Palm
dale and Fortieth St. Schools in
1857. She feels nursing is re-
warding and interesting more to-
day than ever before.


Mrs. Woodward would not give
an estimate of the number Of
pupil visits to her office. She
says most Of them have minor
aches and pains. but the spring
brings more bruises and twisted
ankles.

NEW YORK-Operation Corss-
roads Africa, Inc. private
agency which establishes self
help programs in African coun-
tries with the assistance Of
American, Canadian and African
young people, has completed five
successful years.


DR.. James H. Robinson, found
er and director, reviewed the or
ganization at a recent meeting
of the Overseas Press Club.


He said since 1858 the agency
has sent more than 1000 young
people to Africa during summer
vacations to serve on IS work
projects in Is countries of East.
West and Central Africa.


The participants come from
At states and 9 Canadian proWn-
ces. All helped finance their own
trips usually contributing 40 per
cent Of the cost.


Establishment of the Peace
Corps has not affected the Cross
roads program and interest re-
mains high. Last year 30S appli-
cants were accepted.


This year $40 will assist with
Is projects in 20 countries. Sixty
four requests for Crossroads
projects were received from 80
African nations.


DR.. Robins on, a former Pres
byterian minister in Harlem, said
$50 former Crossr oaders had
volunteered for the Peace Corps.
The agency plans to take an adult
group on a seminar-safari this
Summer

Shown the reception honoring Dr. Allison Davis seated
from left Mesdames Edward Banks and James Billion.


Standing Messrs. James Bilton Norman Men
delsohn DR.. Clarence Laing and Mrs. John Edwards.
Vaughn Phoenix Elementary District superintendent
Marquard editor the Arizona Republic Edward
Banks, Tribune publisher, discuss current -a
